item.description: 1 The stage-discharge relation: hydraulic controls 1.1 Two main types of controls 1.1.1 Section control 1.1.2 Channel control 1.2 Standard controls 1.3 Approximation of real controls by standard controls 2 Hydraulic analysis 2.

item.title: L'Ardèche à Meyras
item.description: 1 Introduction 2 Analyse hydraulique 3 Spécification des a priori 4 Jaugeages et courbe de tarage a posteriori Téléchargez le fichier BaRatinAGE de ce cas d’étude: Ardeche-Meyras.

item.title: Overview
item.description: General information BaRatinAGE v3 is a software package for estimating rating curves and their uncertainties, and for propagating these uncertainties to discharge series. The BaRatin (BAyesian RATINg curve) method is based on a hydraulic analysis of the hydrometric station and Bayesian estimation of the rating curve.

item.title: Hydraulic controls
item.description: 1 Controls 1.1 The basic equation 1.2 Section controls and channel controls 2 Equations of the standard controls 2.1 Rectangular weir 2.2 Parabolic weir 2.

item.description: 1 Analyse hydraulique 2 Spécification des a priori Téléchargez le fichier BaRatinAGE de ce cas d’étude: Isere-Grenoble.bam 1 Analyse hydraulique Cette station peut se modéliser avec un seul contrôle par un chenal rectangulaire large (voir Figure ci-dessous).

item.title: Main frame
item.description: General organisation The window shown below appears when BaRatinAGE v3 starts up: In addition to the classic menu and tool bars (the operation of which will be described in more detail later), this window has several main areas:

item.title: Hydraulic configuration
item.description: Overview The hydraulic configuration is the definition of all the controls that govern the physical stage-discharge relation, and their succession/combination as the water level increases.

item.title: The uncertainties of gaugings
item.description: 1 Uncertain gaugings as calibration data 2 Uncertainties of gauged discharges 3 Uncertainties of gauged stages 1 Uncertain gaugings as calibration data For the analysis of a rating curve with BaRatin, you need to provide a set of gaugings representative of the stage-discharge relation for the study period.

item.title: Gaugings
item.description: The gaugings are nice…

item.title: Rating curve equation
item.description: The equation of the rating curve used in BaRatinAGE is entirely determined by the matrix of controls, an example of which is recalled in the Figure below.

item.title: Structural error model
item.description: Overview Consider the following situation, which is obviously idealised and unrealistic: at a hydrometric station, we have perfect gaugings (i.e. zero uncertainty), and many of them.

item.title: Uncertainties in stage time series
item.description: 1 Error sources 1.1 Instrumental errors or « measurement noise » 1.2 Errors due to free-surface fluctuations 1.3 Errors due to sensor calibration 1.4 Stage representativeness errors 2 Error model used in BaRatinAGE 3 How to estimate stage series uncertainties 3.

item.title: Using RBaM
item.description: 1 Introduction 2 Estimation of a BaRatin rating curve 2.1 Defining streamgauging data 2.2 Defining the rating curve model 2.3 Running BaM and exploring MCMC samples 2.

item.title: Rating curve
item.description: Creating a rating curve A rating curve is a function giving discharge as a function of stage. By default, a blank rating curve called RC (1) pre-exists and can be used.

item.title: Statistical model
item.description: 1 Model and hypotheses 1.1 Gauging errors 1.2 Structural error 1.3 Total error 2 Bayesian estimation 2.1 Information brought by the gaugings: likelihood 2.2 Information brought by hydraulics: prior distribution 2.

item.title: Stage series
item.description: Creating a stage series A stage series (or limnigraph) is a time series of water levels. By default, a stage series named Ht (1) pre-exists and can be used.

item.title: Uncertainties in discharge time series
item.description: This document describes how errors from the rating curve (parametric errors and structural errors) and those from the stage time series (non-systematic and systematic stage measurement errors) are propagated to the discharge time series in BaRatinAGE.

item.title: Bayesian basics
item.description: 1 Introduction : statistical inference 2 Likelihood 2.1 Definition 2.1.1 Discrete random variable 2.1.2 Continuous random variable 2.2 Maximum likelihood estimation 3 Bayesian inference 3.

item.title: Discharge series
item.description: Creating a discharge series A discharge series is a time series of discharge (or streamflow) values. By default, a discharge series named Qt (1) pre-exists and can be used.

item.title: Going further
item.description: Adding a new language To add a language to the interface, all you have to do is to add a column to the glossary file /resources/i18n/translations.

item.title: MCMC Sampling
item.description: 1 Introduction 2 General principle of MCMC samplers 3 The Metropolis algorithm 4 Convergence and representativeness of MCMC simulations 5 Building efficient MCMC samplers 6 MCMC algorithm implemented in BaRatinAGE 1 Introduction The tutorials proposed in the Bayesian Basics page have one peculiarity: there is only one unknown parameter \(\theta\).

item.title: Frequently asked questions
item.description: Note: this section will be updated as we receive more questions. Installation Question: I work on Linux, can I use BaRatinAGE? Answer: Yes, BaRatinAGE 3 can be used on Windows and Linux!
